title: Jordan Henderson praises Anfield spirit for driving Liverpool's title bid
text:

The Anfield nerves have vanished, and Jordan Henderson believes that is driving Liverpool to even greater heights.

Without a title win in 30 years, it is understandable that Reds fans are desperate to see the trophy return to Merseyside…and intensely nervous at the big moments.

That was a feature of the title chase in 2013-14, when nerves often got the better of a stadium which had faced so much heartache over the intervening years since the last league triumph in 1990.

Last season was better though, as Jurgen Klopp’s Liverpool turned Anfield into a fortress, and so far this season, the confidence - and impeccable patience - of the crowd shows just how faith there is in this unbeaten team.

(Image: Getty Images)

For Henderson, it is a huge benefit to the team, displayed in all its positive influence against Spurs, when there were simply no signs of anxiety despite the Reds chasing for much of the game after conceding a shock early goal.

“It’s so difficult for teams to come and play - I here thought the fans were really good again, always keeping us going right until the very end,” he explained.

“That’s why this is a fantastic place to play. Together, we reacted really well, especially after conceding early. That was really pleasing. The performance was really good. Hopefully we can continue in that way.”

(Image: REUTERS)

There was almost a belief around the famous old stadium that Liverpool would come back from that surprise Harry Kane goal after just 47 seconds…and it is completely justified.

The last six times they have gone behind, they have fought back to win, which is an astonishing show of battling spirit.

Henderson typifies that. He has not always had the easiest of relationships with the fans, and held his hand up and took the blame for the Kane goal, when he gave the ball away.

But he showed typical mental strength to not only drive Liverpool forward, but score a hugely important equaliser, his first Anfield goal since December 2015.

(Image: REUTERS)

And he laughed as he was reminded of the previous occasion, against West Brom. “I've been told!” he said, when it was pointed out the wait has been almost four years.

“It was obviously nice to score, get us back in the game. It’s always nice to get on the scoresheet and contribute in that way.

“It was a good time to score as well so [I’m] pleased with that. But like I say all the time, it’s about the win, it’s about the three points and the performance, and that was very good.”
description: The Reds captain grabbed the equaliser against Tottenham in a match that Liverpool never looked like losing
